>

> application
> that I downloaded and use, so I don't want to play with

>

> other ideas are
> welcome):
>
> A) In the DixieCheck class, if the server is not running,
> launch it. I
> must
> admit, I'm new to Java, so I'm not sure of the
> appropriate way to do
> this
> (start another Java application from inside an app,
> like C's system()
> call).
>
> B) Have the dixiecheck Ant task somehow (how?) set a
> "property"and then
> have
> another Ant task that forks java and runs the
> mailserver, if the
> "property"
> is set (can I do a <java fork="yes" classname="..."
> classpath="...">).
>
> Any comments on either of these two? Any other
> suggestions? Any pointers
> on
> A and/or B?

A simple thing to implement right now is to have your task directly call the
<java/> task (in your code base) with a fork attribute set to true. That
way you don't have to know anything about launching processes. If you want
to learn how to launch a process, it shouldn't take you too long. It's very
simple in Java, and there are a couple of tried and true ways of doing it.
Let's take it off-line if you need more help.

As for (B), you would have to add the <property/> support to your task (I
think). Once that is in, you just write a property tag inside the xml
definition of the custom task. Some other target can invoke the
<conditional/> on that property or use the if/unless attribute on the
target.

HTH.
-Jason
